title: Frustrated Lynas rules out compensation battle with Malaysia
text:
Lynas restricted production in the September quarter to ensure it did not reach its lanthanide concentrate processing cap before the end of the calendar year.

The company is in drawn-out negotiations with Malaysian authorities after applying to have the cap lifted.

It was forced to shut its $1 billion processing plant at Kuantan last year after reaching the cap, but is keen to avoid a similar scenario after re-start issues.

Ms Lacaze said the failure to secure approvals with the local regulator was disappointing, but Lynas remained optimistic about a breakthrough before the end of December.

Lynas limited production of neodymium and praseodymium (NdPr), key ingredients in permanent magnets, to 1242 tonnes in the September quarter, compared with 1505 tonnes in the previous three months.

“NdPr production at 1242 tonnes was certainly lower than we would like it to be and lower than we could place in the market, so it is a high priority within our business to resolve this matter,” Ms Lacaze said.

Lynas does not expect a failure to secure the processing increase to affect its plans to self fund a planned $500 million spending spree which includes building a new cracking and leaching plant in Western Australia.

The company must progress plans for the new plant and have approval for a new permanent storage facility in Malaysia for low-level radioactive waste currently stockpiled at Kuantan by March under the terms of a six-month operating licence renewal granted by the Mahathir-led government.

Advertisement

Lynas is understood to favour a site next door to BHP's nickel smelter outside Kalgoorlie for the cracking and leaching plant after also considering building at its Mt Weld rare earths mine near Laverton.

The new plant will remove radioactivity from rare earths material before it is sent to Kuantan for further processing.

Lynas said it saw no roadblocks to meeting the approval deadline for a new home for the waste stockpiled at Kuantan, but it remains unclear if any of the $US42 million in a Permanent Disposal Facility bond held by Malaysia's Atomic Energy Licensing Board can be used toward the cost.

Lynas is due to make another payment of about $US8 million to the bond this quarter.
description: Rare earths producer dials down production after running into another approvals roadblock.
